lessons.Lecture:
In math today, we're diving into the world of real numbers and number systems. We'll define what a real number is and look at different types of number systems, including integers and rational numbers.

To start, let’s define what real numbers are. Real numbers are those numbers that can be found on the number line. This includes both rational numbers, which can be expressed as fractions, and irrational numbers, which cannot be expressed as simple fractions. So, any number that you can think of as a point on the number line is a real number. Examples include whole numbers like 1, 2, and 3, fractions like 1/2 and 3/4, and irrational numbers like the square root of 2 or pi.

Now, I want to take a moment to point toward types of numbers and how they fall into various number systems. The most common number systems we use include natural numbers, whole numbers, integers, rational numbers, and irrational numbers. Natural numbers are simply the positive integers starting from 1 and counting upwards. Whole numbers contain all natural numbers along with zero. Integers include all positive and negative whole numbers, and rational numbers are numbers that can be expressed as a quotient of two integers where the denominator is not zero, such as 1/3 or -7.

$Break time

Let’s talk about the comparisons among whole numbers and integers. Whole numbers, as we mentioned, are numbers without fractions and they never include negative numbers - they start at zero. On the other hand, integers include both positive and negative numbers as well as zero. So, every whole number can be categorized as an integer, but not all integers are classified as whole numbers. This distinction is crucial as it helps us understand where each type of number fits into the broader category of real numbers.

Let’s look at some examples to clarify this. If I say -3, that’s an integer but not a whole number. On the other hand, numbers like 0, 1, and 25 are both whole numbers and integers. Understanding the defining characteristics of these numbers will help you in more complex mathematical problems.

Next, we can explore some practical scenarios where you might use these numbers in everyday life. Think about tracking temperature, where you can go below zero; for this, you’re using integers. But if you are checking off items in a list where you can’t have negative items, here you would only think in terms of whole numbers. 

$Break time

To tie this all together, let’s briefly look back at real numbers and the number systems we discussed. Real numbers encompass a variety of unique categories that serve different purposes in mathematics. Natural numbers help us count things, whole numbers help us include zero, integers let us handle positive and negative quantities, and rational numbers allow us to express parts of self-contained wholes.

Understanding real numbers is foundational for tackling more complex algebra concepts and eventually calculus. You’ll see as we advance that these basics are indeed building blocks for everything more intricate.

In summary, today you have learned about the definition of real numbers and how they exist within several important number systems. We covered the characteristics of natural numbers, whole numbers, integers, and rational numbers. We also compared whole numbers and integers to better grasp their differences. This fundamental knowledge sets the stage for further exploration into more advanced mathematics. Keep this in mind as we move forward, as these concepts will be essential in the lessons to come!
lessons.summary: Today's lesson introduced you to the world of real numbers and number systems. You learned the definition of real numbers, explored various number systems including natural numbers, whole numbers, integers, and rational numbers, and compared whole numbers and integers. This forms the foundation for more complex math topics!
